Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Situation2: They set aside part of their routine to light a lamp and offer prayers at their home altar.
Story:
Every evening, as the sun dipped below the rooftops, I was expected to join my family in the living room, where we would share stories and laughter, keeping alive the traditions my grandparents cherished. Lately, my parents had become even more insistent that I be present, reminding me how important it was to honor our family’s customs, especially now that my grandparents were growing older. But at the same time, as a practicing Hindu, I had promised myself to light the lamp and offer prayers at our home altar at dusk—a ritual that brought me peace and a sense of connection to something greater.

Tonight, the timing clashed. My family called me to join them just as I was about to begin my prayers. I could hear their voices, warm and expectant, but I also felt the pull of my spiritual duty, the quiet altar waiting for me. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, torn between the laughter of my family and the silent glow of the lamp. I wanted to be the devoted child they hoped for, but I also longed to honor my faith. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I hesitated, caught between two worlds.
